main event: Observers at Point Barrow, Alaska, spotted a light in the sky while tracking a balloon. The light, identified as the planet Jupiter, moved from East to West at a rate of 3-4 degrees per minute and was in view for approximately six hours.
interesting points: The observation lasted for an unusually long duration, lasting approximately six hours.
The light was moving at a slow rate, approximately 3-4 degrees per minute from East to West.
Astronomer Dr. Sibley stated an opinion that the light was definitely a planet, likely Venus, while AMC plotted the object as Jupiter.
The observation was made through a 20-power theodolite, indicating a ground-visual type of observation.
The document included a request for a detailed report of the sighting and theodolite readings taken during the observation.
